importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the sexual assault occurred at Gettysburg College, marking the beginning of a long-delayed legal pursuit.
The year Keeler shared her experience in an AP story highlighting the reluctance of prosecutors to pursue campus sexual assault cases.
The date Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy charge, which ultimately led to his extradition to the U.S.
The date of the sentencing of Ian Cleary, marking a culmination of a 12-year legal and emotional journey for the victim.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 12-year span from the assault to the sentencing highlights systemic failures in campus sexual assault investigations and the long-term trauma experienced by victims.

keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a woman at Gettysburg College in 2013 was sentenced to two to four years in prison after being extradited from France.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, pursued charges for over a decade, with prosecutors initially reluctant to file due to campus sexual assault challenges.
The case underscores systemic issues in how campus sexual assault cases are handled, including the destruction of evidence and long delays in prosecution.
Ian Cleary, who pleaded guilty and admitted to sending a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you,' claimed it was part of a 12-step program to seek atonement.
The judge acknowledged Cleary’s remorse, mental illness, and guilty plea, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines.
Keeler emphasized that the legal system failed her initially, and the eventual prosecution was a painful but necessary reckoning.
Cleary had a history of mental illness, lived in Silicon Valley and worked for Tesla, and was eventually extradited after being detained in France on a separate charge.

namedEntities.name: Ian Cleary
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A man who sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College in 2013 and was later extradited from France. He pleaded guilty to second-degree sexual assault and sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you.' He was sentenced to two to four years in prison.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cleary is the central figure in the case, representing both the perpetrator and the broader issue of accountability in sexual assault cases where victims wait years for justice.

namedEntities.name: Shannon Keeler
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The victim of the 2013 sexual assault at Gettysburg College. She initiated and pursued legal action over a 12-year period, speaking publicly about the system’s failure to protect her.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Keeler’s public advocacy highlights the challenges victims face in seeking justice, especially in campus sexual assault cases where evidence is destroyed and prosecution is often delayed.

namedEntities.name: Gettysburg College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The college in Pennsylvania where the sexual assault occurred in 2013, and where Cleary was a student.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The college setting underscores the complexities of campus sexual assault investigations, including institutional inaction and reluctance to pursue charges.

namedEntities.name: Senior Judge Kevin Hess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judge who presided over Cleary’s sentencing, noting the horror of the crime and the defendant’s remorse.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Judge Hess provided a judicial perspective on the crime, emphasizing the emotional toll on victims and the significance of accountability despite long delays.

namedEntities.name: Andrea Levy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Shannon Keeler’s lawyer, who criticized the sentence as insufficient but expressed relief that the case was closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Levy represents the legal support system for victims and offers insight into the expectations and limitations of legal outcomes in such cases.

namedEntities.name: Tesla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The company where Ian Cleary worked after completing his education, indicating his professional trajectory post-attack.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cleary’s employment at Tesla illustrates how perpetrators can move through society and evade accountability for years.

namedEntities.name: Metz, France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The city where Ian Cleary was detained in April 2024 on a vagrancy charge, which led to his eventual extradition to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Metz serves as a key location in the international effort to locate and bring Cleary to justice, demonstrating the cross-border complexity of prosecuting sexual assault cases.

namedEntities.name: Associated Press (AP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The news outlet that published Keeler’s story in 2021, raising awareness about prosecutorial reluctance in campus sexual assault cases.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AP article catalyzed renewed efforts to pursue the case, showing how media coverage can influence legal action and public awareness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison on October 20, 2025, for sexually assaulting a woman, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013. After being extradited from France in 2024, Cleary pleaded guilty and sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you,' which reopened wounds for Keeler. The case took over a decade to pursue due to prosecutorial reluctance, evidence destruction, and Cleary’s long absence from campus. Judge Kevin Hess considered Cleary’s remorse, mental illness, and guilty plea, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines. Keeler, who has spoken publicly about her trauma, described the case as a painful but necessary reckoning with a system that failed her. The incident highlights systemic issues in campus sexual assault investigations, including delayed prosecution and lack of accountability.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After 12-Year Delay in Campus Sexual Assault Case
